passages.text: Inflows to HG slowed due to funds. Flows to HY and stocks tapered, while inflows to loans was unchanged this past week ending August 27.

Inflows moderated for US HG bond funds and ETFs, with a \(+57.29bn\) inflow down from a \(+\) 8.58bn inflow in the prior week. This was driven by slowdown HG Funds (to \(+\) 1.25bn from \(+\) 3.51bn) as inflows improved for HG ETFs (to \(+\) 6.04bn from \(+\) 5.07bn). Inflows slowed for Inflows moderated for both short- term HG (to \(+\) 0.71bn from \(+\) 1.24bn) and ex. short- term (to \(+\) 6.57bn from \(+\) 7.34bn).

Inflows were better for loans (to \(+\) 0.83bn from \(+\) 0.65bn), while outflows accelerated for HY (to - 0.69bn, the biggest outflow in 4 months, from - 0.63bn). Flows again flipped positive for equities this past week (to \(+\) 10.47bn from - 2.37bn), while Inflows moderated for global EM bonds (to \(+\) 0.84bn from \(+\) 3.25bn) and for munis (to \(+\) 0.92bn from \(+\) 2.87bn). Finally, money markets reported a \(+\) 30.15bn inflow this past week, following a - 15.56bn outflow a week earlier.

HG ETF inflow was \(+\) 6.04bn this past week ending Aug- 27 (vs \(+\) 5.07bn a week prior), and HG Funds inflow was \(+\) 1.25bn (vs \(+\) 3.51bn a week prior). Since Sept 2024, both HG Funds and ETFs, the 12- week moving average have declined into end of 2024 and April 2025. Flows have rebounded since then.
Source: EPFR Global. Note: data are for US domiciled funds only.

BofA Securities does and seeks to do business with issuers covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. Refer to important disclosures on page 25 to 27.
Credit Strategy United States Cross Product
Daily supply snapshot Daily dealer inventories update Daily HG fund flows Daily foreign demand tracker Weekly data and charts

Equities inflow was +\(10.47bn this past week ending Aug-27 (vs -\)2.37bn a week prior). As shown by the weekly equity flows and its 12-week moving average, since Sept 2024 flows accelerated into Dec 2024 and has decreased since then.
Source: EPFR Global. Note: data are for US-domiciled funds only.
As of Aug-27, YtD flows are 4% of AUM for HG, 4% for HY, 10% for loans, and 0% for equities.
High yield: ETFs only has had the biggest inflows so far in 2025 as of Aug-27 at (19.4% of AUM), followed by Loans (10.1%).

HG short- term flow was \(+50.71bn\) this past week ending Aug- 27 (vs \(+\) 1.24bn a week prior), and HG ex short- term flow was \(+\) 6.57bn (vs \(+\) 7.34bn a week prior). Both short term and ex- short term flows have stayed stable since 09/2024 before declining sharply in April but has rebounded since then.
Source: EPFR Global. Note: data are for US-domiciled funds only.

Leveraged loans inflow was \(+\) 0.83bn this past week ending Aug- 27 (vs \(+\) 0.65bn a week prior). Since 09/2024, loan inflows accelerated into Jan 2025 then declined sharply in April, and then rebounded moderately/
Source: EPFR Global. Note: data are for US-domiciled funds only.

HY ETF inflow was - 0.36bn this past week ending Aug- 27 (vs - 0.88bn a week prior), and HY Funds inflow was - 0.33bn (vs +0.25bn a week prior). Both HY Funds and ETF flows since 09/2024 declined into April 2025 but has rebounded since then,
Source: EPFR Global. Note: data are for US-domiciled funds only.
Global EM bond inflow was \(+\) 0.84bn this past week ending Aug- 27 (vs \(+\) 3.25bn a week prior). Since Sept 2024, EM flows soared led by EM Local funds.
Source: EPFR Global. Note: data are for US-domiciled funds only.

Appendix: defining high gradeWe define our high grade flows metric as a combination of "bond" and "corporate bond" fixed income funds and ETFs domiciled in the US (and investing in any currency, although the majority is invested in USD). We also exclude funds primarily focused on Government, HY, EM and MBS from the sample. The "bond" category refers to the broad high grade market, which includes Treasuries, mortgages and agencies in addition to corporate bonds. This category accounts for the majority of AUM and flows. On the other hand the dedicated corporate bond funds and ETFs are much smaller in terms of assets under management. We also include the "total return" bond category in our tracking of high grade flows. Finally note that "short-term" maturity refers to duration of 0 to 4 years.
US IG issuance totaled \$0bn across no deal today, \$3.4bn WTD and \$101.6bn MTD. This week's new issues are trading 5bps tighter on average from pricing.
List of new issues in the IG corporate bond market today along with performance metrics. This week's supply is $32.7bn WtD, compared to $32.7bn supply last week.

Note: We calculate new issue concessions by estimating the difference between new issue bond spread and interpolated G spread from comparable liquid secondary bonds of the same issuer prior to the new issue deal announcement, adjusted for the spread impact of dollar prices deviating from par. Break performance is computed as the difference between new issue pricing and secondary closing spread on the first day of trading.
Source: BofA Global Research

Below we estimate dealer inventories for the IG corporate bonds based on TRACE data.The actual inventories of US issuer bonds based on NY Fed survey, as well as the estimated change since the latest Fed report are plotted in Exhibit 14. We estimate the corresponding DV01 equivalent in Exhibit 15. More details by sector and maturity are available in Exhibit 16 and Exhibit 17. Finally, note that the data for the current date is through about 4:40 p.m. Eastern Standard Time.
We estimate IG dealer inventories of US issuer bonds increased to -$3.2bn currently on Aug-28 from -$3.8bn on Aug-20. Since Aug 2024, dealer inventories have steadily decreased.

Note: data for US issuer bonds only, maturities 13M or longer. Actual dealer inventory data is from Primary Dealer Statistics survey by the NY Fed. The subsequent change in inventory is estimated based on TRACE and IG ETF flows.
Source: BofA Global Research, FINRA, TRACE, Federal Reserve
We estimate IG dealer inventory DV01 of US issuer bonds increased to -$5.7mn currently on Aug-28 from -$6.4bn on Aug-20. Since Aug 2024, dealer inventories have steadily decreased.

Note: data for US issuer bonds only, maturities 13M or longer. Actual dealer inventory data is from Primary Dealer Statistics survey by the NY Fed. The subsequent change in inventory is estimated based on TRACE and IG ETF flows.
**Source**: BofA Global Research, FINRA, TRACE, Federal Reserve
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

We define our high grade flows as a combination of “bond” and “corporate bond” fixed income funds and ETFs domiciled in the US (and investing in any currency, although the majority is invested in USD). We also exclude funds primarily focused on Government,HY, EM and MBS from the sample. The “bond” category refers to the broad high grade market, which includes Treasuries, mortgages and agencies in addition to corporate bonds. This category accounts for the majority of AUM and flows.
On Aug-27, daily IG inflow was $647mn, down from $1,350mn on Aug-26.Since May 29 2025, daily flows have increased between June-mid July, and since beginning of August.

Average daily inflow to HG was $2,345mn in August, up from $1,561mn in July. Average daily. Since July 2024, average daily inflow has decreased into April 2025 and has rebounded since then.

half of funds report flows daily.

HG fund flows tend to follow returns, as shown below since Aug- 2022, although flows have been decoupled from returns since around Oct- 2024. 2M price return dropped by - 24bps in the last 4 weeks ending Aug- 27, while 10- day MA daily flows were up by \(\) 959\mathrm{m}\$ during the same period.
Source: BofA Global Research, ICE Data Indices, LLC

Trading overnight (prior to 8am) as well as with affiliates are proxies for foreign demand for USD IG corporate bonds. Negative values for "net dealer buy" denote net buying by foreign investors (i.e. US dealers taking down inventory in favor of foreign affiliates). Exhibit 21 and Exhibit 22 show net dealer- to- all volumes before 8am ET (biased toward Asian demand) while Exhibit 23 and Exhibit 24 show net dealer- to- affiliates volumes between 8am and noon (biased toward European demand). Exhibit 25 shows the relationship between foreign buying and change in treasury yields. A drop in yield typically leads to lower foreign demand, though not always.

Net dealer buy prior to 8am is a proxy for Asian demand for USD IG corp bonds 1- 10yr since Dec- 2024 until Aug- 2025. The corresponding net dealer volume was \(\) 10\(mn on Aug - 28, vs\) \ \(mn\) the day prior.
Note: Morning share of daily trading volume is correlated with secondary market activity of foreign investors due to different time zones. Source: BofA Global Research, TRACE

Net dealer buy prior to 8am is a proxy for Asian demand for USD IG corp bonds 1- 10yr since Dec- 2024 until Aug- 2025. The corresponding net dealer volume was \(\) 10\(mn on Aug - 28, vs\) \ \(60mn\) the day prior.

Net dealer buy prior to 8am is a proxy for Asian demand for USD IG corp bonds 1- 10yr since Dec- 2024 until Aug- 2025. The corresponding net dealer volume was \(\) 293\(mn on Aug - 28, vs\) \ \(125mn\) the day prior.
Note: Morning share of daily trading volume is correlated with secondary market activity of foreign investors due to different time zones. Source: BofA Global Research, TRACE

Net dealer buy prior to 8am is a proxy for Asian demand for USD IG corp bonds 1- 10yr since Dec- 2024 until Aug- 2025. The corresponding net dealer volume was \(\) 66mn\(on Aug - 28, vs\) \ \(40mn\) the day prior.
Note: Morning share of daily trading volume is correlated with secondary market activity of foreign investors due to different time zones. Source: BofA Global Research, TRACE

A drop in Treasury yield typically leads to lower foreign demand, as shown below from Apr- 2024to Aug- 2025. We estimate 12- day MA foreign buy went down by \(5 - 107mm\) over the past 5 business days ending Aug- 28, while T yield decreased by 0bps over the same period.
Note: Net foreign buying is defined as the sum of net dealer buy before 8am ET and net dealer-to-affiliates volume between 8am and noon ET. Source: BofA Global Research, TRACE, Bloomberg

Sector spreads for BofA US IG Corporate Index COAO as of August 27, 2025. Sectors with the tightest spreads are Retail- Discounters (44bps) and Consumer Products (54bps), while sectors with the widest spreads are Pipelines (105bps) and P&C & Reinsurance (96bps). Results include subordinated and hybrid securities.
Source: BofA Global Research, ICE Data Indices, LLC

Sector spreads and performance for BofA HG U.S. Corporate Master COAO. Transportation- Other had the largest MTD excess return at 45bps, while Paper and Forest Products had the lowest MTD excess return at - 8bps. Results include subordinated and hybrid securities.

Sector spreads and performance for BofA HG U.S. Corporate Master COAO. Transportation-Other had the largest MTD excess return at 45bps, while Paper and Forest Products had the lowest MTD excess return at -8bps. Results include subordinated and hybrid securities.
Source: ICE Data Indices, LLC, BofA Global Research
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Exhibit 35:5s10s non- financial corporate spread curves 5s10s spread curves have steepened YTD, and flattened since Aug- 2023.

Note: the spread curve calculation is restricted to issuers that have bonds outstanding for both the short and the long tenors. For spread levels we use only on-the-run bonds (one for each tenor), outstanding for at most three years. The aggregate market spread curve is a simple average of individual issuer curves.
Source:BofA Global Research, ICE Data Indices, LLC
Exhibit 36:10s30s non-financial corporate spread curves 10s30s IG spread has flattened YTD as 30yr Treasury rose, and it flattened as 30yr yield rose since Aug-2023.

Note: the spread curve calculation is restricted to issuers that have bonds outstanding for both the short and the long tenors. For spread levels we use only on-the-run bonds (one for each tenor), outstanding for at most three years. The aggregate market spread curve is a simple average of individual issuer curves. 5s10s large US bank spread curves have flattened YTD, and flattened since Aug- 2023.

Exhibit 46: European issuers: relative EUR and USD spreads Relative value between fully currency hedged EUR and USD spreads for US issuers is at - 15bps as of Aug- 18, above the average from 2010, and down from - 5bps on Aug- 28- 2018.

Note: the chart plots issuer- matched spreads on a fully currency hedged basis. We use maturity- matched cross currency basis swaps to fully currency hedge principal and interest rate payments, and forward FX rates to fully hedge the stream of spread payments. We also adjust for the difference in quoting conventions with a 3 to 6M Euribor swap. Source: BofA Global Research, ICE Data Indices, LLC, Bloomberg
Source: BofA Global Research, ICE Data Indices, LLC, Bloomberg
